FranÃ§ois Arnaud came out as bisexual in a string of Instagram stories Sunday evening (20 September).

item.title: Louis Theroux pays moving tribute to trans woman who died after starring in his prison documentary

media:thumbnail.caption: The filmmaker had interviewed Deborah Lee Worledge in his 2007 documentary Behind Bars. (BBC)

item.description: Louis Theroux has spoken about a trans woman who died to a drug overdose a year after she was interviewed for his prison documentary.
item.dc:creator: Nick Duffy
item.content:encoded:
Louis Theroux has spoken about a trans woman who died to a drug overdose a year after she was interviewed for his prison documentary.

The filmmaker had interviewed Deborah Lee Worledge in his 2007 documentary Behind Bars, which explored life in the US prison system.

At the time Deborah, who had a decades-long record of minor criminal offences, was serving a three-month sentence for robbery at San Quentin, a menâ€™s prison in California.

When Theroux first interviewed the inmate, she was revealed to be in a loving and compassionate relationship with her cellmate, Robert.

Louis Theroux shares tragic update on trans woman featured in prison documentary.

Revisiting the documentary as part of his new series Life on the Edge, Theroux reflected: â€œShortly after the interview, Deborah was released.

â€œShe to me represented something about San Quentin, which was that very often things werenâ€™t quite as you would expect. Nothing was quire as simple as you might imagine it would be.

â€œYou expect brutality in prison, and violence and antagonism, so what becomes surprising is when you see something else. Itâ€™s not simply chaos, mayhem, negativity.

â€œIf you become habituated to a certain way of living, that becomes more normal, or at least more known, than what you have on the outside.â€

He added: â€œThe following year, after we filmed, Deborah was back inside, and then released.

â€œShe died of a drug overdose on September 4, 2008 two days later. She is missed by many.â€

Theroux continued: â€œShe had a romantic notion of being an outlaw. She was the one who said to me: â€˜Itâ€™s like in the movies. thereâ€™s cops and thereâ€™s robbers, and weâ€™re the robbers.â€™

â€œShe seemed to have seen the streets as a more accepting place than, as it were, mainstream society. Thereâ€™s a kind of self-respect in the aspect of street code.

â€œIt might seem self-destructive, but in other ways itâ€™s the best they can do in the situation theyâ€™re in.â€

Deborah Lee Worledge: â€˜Todayâ€™s a different dayâ€™.

The new documentary features a short clip of Deborah speaking to photographer Robert Gumpert in 2008, shortly before her death.

In the full clip, she expresses her hope that as trans people become more accepted in society, they would have a route to a better life.

She says: â€œYears ago back in the 80s, when t****ies were growing up and coming of age, there was no place for us in society and we were kind of put out on the fringes of society.

â€œWe were allowed by society to be the hookers late at night, do little petty crimes, be little petty drug dealers, but we were never allowed to be in somebodyâ€™s business, to represent their business standing at the counter.

â€œThe real safe place for us was out there on the streets, in the little underworld or whatever you want to call it, being petty criminals, coming in and out of jails and stuff.

â€œIâ€™ve done a nine year term, and a 13 year term back to back in prison behind. Growing up out there on the street.

â€œTodayâ€™s a different day, though, because now transsexuals are in the non-profits, and theyâ€™re being allowed to become functioning members of the community, things are becoming much more accepted.

â€œWeâ€™re not all Jerry Springer. And I feel pretty confident about the upward movement of my community, and proud to be a part of it.â€

Louis Theroux has previously said that he regrets parts of the original 2007 documentary, which referred to Deborah by her birth name and used male pronouns for her during voice-over segments.

He explained to UniLad that since the documentary series was filmed, â€œit feels like the worldâ€™s moved on and all cultural norms have changedâ€.

He said: â€œIt feels like maybe thereâ€™s moments that donâ€™t feel quite right, or feel like they would be phrased differently now.

â€œThereâ€™s moments where because of the nature of sensitivities now, and how much more educated we are, the conversation would take place in a different way.â€

item.content:encoded:
Allison Jones Rushing, one of Donald Trumpâ€™s top picks to replace Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the US Supreme Court, has worrying links to an anti-LGBT+ hate group.

Rushing is one of the 20 potential conservative nominees Trump listed earlier this month, just weeks before before Ginsburg passed away and left a vacancy on the US Supreme Court.

Trump plans to replace RBG, as she was affectionately known, imminently, and has vowed to announce a woman as his nominee this week.

Rushing is one of the most prominent female potential nominees on Trumpâ€™s list, and has a concerning anti-LGBT+ history. According to CNNâ€™s Daniel Dale, Trump boasted that one of his shortlisted candidates â€˜â€is 38 years old and could serve on the court for 50 yearsâ€, which Dale says is â€œalmost certainlyâ€ Rushing.

Trump notes that one of the candidates on his SCOTUS short list (almost certainly Allison Jones Rushing) is 38 years old and could serve on the court for 50 years. He sarcastically says Democrats are "thrilled" about that prospect.

â€” Daniel Dale (@ddale8) September 21, 2020

The judge was confirmed to the fourth US Circuit Court of Appeals in March 2019, but many LGBT+ organisations expressed alarm over the judgeâ€™s decade-long association with well-known anti-LGBT+ hate group Alliance Defending Freedom (ADF).

ADF is an anti-LGBT+ legal group, which has been classified by the Southern Poverty Law Center as an anti-LGBT+ hate group. The organisation has supported criminalising gay sex in America and abroad, fought for the state-enforced sterilisation of trans people, and has linked being gay to paedophilia.

According to NBC News, Rushing was an intern for ADF as a law student in 2005. She authored amicus briefs for clients in support of the ADFâ€™s conservative views, and co-authored a legal brief on â€œreligious libertyâ€. Between 2012 and 2017, Rushing spoke at ADF events at least once a year.

Allison Rushing has supported and closely associated herself with one of the most extreme anti-LGBT organisations operating in this country today.

Ian Wilhite, a spokesperson for Lambda Legal, said in a statement at the time of Rushingâ€™s senate confirmation: â€œThroughout her brief legal career, Allison Rushing has supported and closely associated herself with one of the most extreme anti-LGBT organisations operating in this country today, the Alliance Defending Freedom.â€

Vanita Gupta, president and CEO of The Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights, also told CNN in a statement at the time: â€œHer record clearly shows she will not be a fair and independent judge â€” a reality with dire consequences for Fourth Circuit cases and the American people.â€

Ruth Bader Ginsburg died at her home on Friday evening (September 18) from complications of metastatic cancer of the pancreas, prompting an outpouring of love and praise for the equal rights champion and feminist icon and an immediate political firestorm.

Democrats have called for a delay in replacing Ginsburg, following a precedent set during the final year of Barack Obamaâ€™s presidency, when Republicans senate majority leader Mitch McConnell declared a replacement would not be approved, and that the next president would instead choose his or her pick following the election.

However Friday (September 18), McConnell was adamant that a vote would be held on Trumpâ€™s nominee. Ted Cruz has argued that there is a different precedent for times when the White House and Senate are controlled by the same party, which wasnâ€™t the case under Obama.

Until Ginsburgâ€™s death, the supreme court had a 5 to 4 Republican majority. Should Trumpâ€™s nominee be appointed, this would shift to a stronger 6 to 3 conservative majority which could remain in place for decades, shaping major legal decision in the US for years to come.

item.title: Tens of thousands plead with government to reform Gender Recognition Act after report claims self-ID has been dropped

media:thumbnail.caption: Minister for Women and Equalities Liz Truss (Wiktor Szymanowicz/Barcroft Media via Getty Images)

item.description: Tens of thousands of people have signed a petition calling on the government to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act (GRA) ahead of a looming announcement on the issue.
item.dc:creator: Nick Duffy
item.content:encoded:
Tens of thousands of people have signed a petition calling on the government to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act (GRA) ahead of a looming announcement on the issue.

The Sunday Times has reported that equalities minister Liz Truss is poised to ditch plans to allow trans people to change the gender on their birth certificate without seeking approval from doctors â€” opting to largely ignore the results of a 2018 consultation that found overwhelming public support for the change.

The newspaperâ€™s report is the latest in the series of leaks concerning GRA reform, which has faced an uncertain future and repeated delays since Truss was handed the equalities brief by Boris Johnson.

On Monday, a Government Equalities Office spokesperson confirmed to PinkNews: â€œThe minister for women and equalities will provide the governmentâ€™s response to the Gender Recognition Act this week.â€

Petition calls for GRA reform to continue.

Ahead of the imminent announcement, a petition calling for the reforms to go ahead has attracted more than 64,000 signatures in just over a day.

It states: â€œReform the GRA to allow transgender people to self-identify without the need for a medical diagnosis, to streamline the administrative process, and to allow non-binary identities to be legally recognised.

â€œThe response gathered by the government showed strong support for this reform with 70 per cent in favour, but the results seem to have been ignored by policy makers.

â€œThe current process is distressing and often humiliating for transgender people, as well as lengthy and costly making it inaccessible to many people.

â€œReform is needed to improve the lives of trans people, and I donâ€™t think the proposed measures will negatively impact existing provisions under the [Equality] Act.â€

Campaigners have long called for the UKâ€™s gender recognition laws, which are 16 years out of date and do not align with international best practice, to be modernised.

The existing laws require trans people to clear a number of hurdles to change their legal gender, including the provision of â€œevidence of living in an acquired genderâ€, submission of a medical report detailing treatment they received, and payment of a Â£140 fee.

A large percentage of trans people do not seek a gender recognition certificate due to the bureaucratic burden, medicalised process, high cost and perceived lack of benefit. Others, such as under-18s and non-binary people, are denied access to gender recognition certificates entirely.

A gender recognition certificate is not required to update gender on ID documents such as passports or driverâ€™s licenses, it has no connection whatsoever to access to single-sex spaces, and itâ€™s illegal for businesses to require one to be provided as evidence of gender.

â€˜Trans people have waited too long for equality.â€™

LGBT+ charity Stonewall said in a statement on Sunday: â€œFor years, trans communities have said the GRA is outdated. The British public overwhelmingly agreed and called for reform via consultation.

â€œTrade unions and doctors just this week re-affirmed their support for reform. Trans people have waited too long for equality.

â€œNow, if todayâ€™s report is true and the government doesnâ€™t move forward with real GRA reform it will be a bitter blow for trans people.

â€œBut what hasnâ€™t changed is trans peopleâ€™s legal right to access single-sex spaces in line with the gender they identify with.â€

Stonewall added: â€œThis news wonâ€™t change the fact that in a landmark ruling this week, an employment tribunal decided that Equality Act protections cover non-binary and gender fluid people.

A BBC journalist asked the prime minister of Barbados, Mia Mottley, if people should be â€œallowedâ€ to be gay â€“ and she did not hold back.

Mottley appeared on BBC News to discuss revived plans for the Caribbean island to remove the queen as its head of state and become a republic.

In the interview with BBC journalist Christian Fraser, Mottley spoke about constitutional reform in Barbados, and the topic of LGBT+ rights came up.

Barbados recently agreed to recognise same-sex civil unions, as the tiny island nation unpicks its colonial-era homosexuality laws.

Although the government asserted that it is not yet allowing same-sex marriage, it has agreed to put the matter to a referendum and â€œbe guided by the vote of the publicâ€.

Referencing the upcoming referendum, Fraser asked the prime minister: â€œFor that next generation, should they be allowed to be gay in Barbados?â€

Looking incredulous, Mottley said: â€œSorry?â€

But Fraser persisted with the question, repeating more slowly: â€œShould people in Barbados be allowed to be gay, to be homosexual?â€

Mottley, who has taken a progressive stance on LGBT+ rights in Barbados, was quick to put the journalist in his place.

She said: â€œIs that a question you would ask the United Kingdom?â€

Fraser refused to back down, adding: â€œWell, we have laws on gay marriage and youâ€™re having a referendum on gay marriage.â€

The irony that the colonial-era laws which oppress LGBT+ people in Barbados were put in place by the British escaped the BBC journalist.

item.title: Tyler Perry pays tribute to LGBT+ storytellers in powerfully personal Emmys acceptance speech

media:thumbnail.caption: Tyler Perry gave a rousing speech as he accepted his Emmy Award. (YouTube)

item.description: Tyler Perry celebrated LGBT+ and BIPOC storytellers at the Emmy Awards 2020, accepting the Governorâ€™s Ward for outstanding achievement.
item.dc:creator: Reiss Smith
item.content:encoded:
Tyler Perry celebrated LGBT+ and BIPOC storytellers at the Emmy Awards 2020, accepting the Governorâ€™s Ward for outstanding achievement.

The filmmaker â€” recently coined a billionaire by Forbes â€” made history at the Emmys as the first Black person to ever be individually awarded the honour, which celebrates a talent â€œso extraordinary and universal in natureâ€ it surpasses the scope of all other categories.

Tyler Perry accepted the award on behalf of himself and his Perry Foundation with a rousing speech which championed Black, Asian, Latin and LGBT+ filmmakers, and took the form of a deeply personal anecdote about a seemingly worthless quilt his grandmother gave him when he was 19 years old.

â€œThis quilt was something I didnâ€™t really care for,â€ Perry explained.

â€œIt had all these different colours and these different patches in it. And I was quite embarrassed by it. I had no value in it at all.â€

The Madea creator â€“ the only winner to accept their award in person â€“ explained how he would use his grandmotherâ€™s quilt to dry off his dog and to lie on when changing the oil in his car.

â€œI had no respect for this quilt,â€ he continued.

â€œMany years later, as I was walking past those fancy antique stores that I could finally go in and shop, I saw in the window a quilt that looked just like the one that she had given me.â€

In the store, an attendant approached Perry and told him the significance of this quilt. It had been sewn by a Black American woman who had formerly been enslaved. Each patch was part of the tapestry of her life: from a square of the dress she had been wearing when she learned she was a free woman, to a patch taken from the wedding dress she wore as she â€œjumped the broomâ€.

I dismissed her work and her story because it didnâ€™t look like what I thought it should.

â€œAnd as I was hearing this story, I became so embarrassed,â€ he continued. â€œHere I was, a person who prides myself on celebrating our heritage, our culture, and I didnâ€™t even recognise the value in my grandmotherâ€™s quilt.

â€œI dismissed her work and her story because it didnâ€™t look like what I thought it should. Now, whether we know it or not, we are all sewing our own quilts with our thoughts, our behaviours, our experiences and our memories.â€

In his own quilt, Perry said, would be a memory of his father standing by the front door, waiting for the white man who employed him to deliver his wages. He never did, and Perry recalled his mother saying: â€œDonâ€™t you ever stand by a door waiting for white folks to do nothing for you.â€

Though Perryâ€™s mother â€œwasnâ€™t a racistâ€, he explained, it was impossible for her to imagine her son breaking free of the system which had oppressed her own family ofor generations.

â€œIn my motherâ€™s quilt, she couldnâ€™t imagine me owning land that was once a Confederate Army base where Confederate soldiers plotted and planned on how to keep Blacks enslaved,â€ he said, referring to his 330-acre Tyler Perry Studios, Americaâ€™s largest film production studio and the only one owned outright by an African American person.

â€œAnd now, on that very land, Black people, white people, gay, straight, lesbian, transgender, ex-cons, Latin, Asian, all of us, come together, working,â€ he concluded.

â€œAll coming together to add patches to a quilt that is as diverse as it can be. Diversity at its best.â€

Zendaya won her first Emmy at the virtual 2020 ceremony, taking home Best Drama Actress for her part in Euphoria.

Zendaya, 24, made history as the categoryâ€™s youngest-ever winner, beating off competition from industry stalwarts Olivia Colman (The Crown), Jennifer Aniston (The Morning Show), Laura Linney (Ozark) and last-yearâ€™s winner â€“ who held the previous record at 26 years old â€“ Jodie Comer (Killing Eve).

The Euphoria star also becomes only the second Black woman to win the category in the Emmysâ€™ 71-year history, after Viola Davis (How to Get Away With Murder, in 2015).

Zendaya accepted her Emmy from home surrounded by family, supporters and her dog Noon.

â€œThis is pretty crazy, I donâ€™t really cry,â€ she said, visibly shaken, to a chorus of screams.

â€œIâ€™m inspired by every thing that you do,â€ she added.

Zendaya has been a vocal advocate for Black Lives Matter and nodded to the current social and political climate in her Emmys speech, paying tribute to young activists.

â€œI know this feels like is a really weird time to be celebrating,â€ she said. â€œBut I just want to say there is hope in the young people out there, I know that our TV show doesnâ€™t always feel like a great example of that, but there is hope in the young people.â€

She added: â€œTo all my peers out there doing the work in the streets: I see you, I admire you, I thank you.â€
